meanings.definition: To increase the volume or fullness of something.
meanings.sent1: She used a special shampoo to volumise her hair before the party.
meanings.sent2: The stylist knew how to volumise thin hair to make it look thicker.
meanings.sent3: Trying to volumise a deflated balloon only made it more wrinkled.
meanings.sent4: The music seemed to volumise the room, filling every corner with sound.
meanings.sent5: The chef added extra spices to volumise the flavor of the dish.

meanings.definition: To make something appear larger or fuller.
meanings.sent1: The magician used mirrors to volumise the illusion of a disappearing act.
meanings.sent2: The new dress design was meant to volumise the wearer's figure.
meanings.sent3: The artist's painting technique could volumise a simple canvas into a masterpiece.
meanings.sent4: The clouds seemed to volumise the sky, creating a dramatic sunset.
meanings.sent5: The marketing team decided to volumise the product packaging to attract more customers.

meanings.definition: The act of adding volume or fullness to something.
meanings.sent1: Her volumise of the hair gave it a glamorous look for the event.
meanings.sent2: The volumise of the cake with extra frosting made it a hit at the party.
meanings.sent3: The comedian's joke had a volumise of laughter from the audience.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brush strokes added a volumise to the painting, making it come alive.
meanings.sent5: The stylist's skillful volumise of the client's hair left them feeling confident and stylish.
